section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builder: Motivation and Creativity; Social Development

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to review math background, engage children with song, and introduce vocabulary (fold, origami).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking, What is one thing Joey folded in the story?
Read for enjoyment, with a focus on shapes.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Explain that a shape remains the same shape even when its size or position changes; Recognize, name, and describe common two-dimensional shapes using words related to number of sides, length of sides, and number of points or angles.
Take initiative.
Engage with trusted adults and peers to work, communicate, and play.
Use art for self-expression.
Remove a word from a compound word.
Children understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Choose an Activity Card and give hints as to what shape is on it.
Guide children to guess the shape or ask for more information.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we express ourselves through making art?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What shape is your book cover?
Pretend to be an artist. What kind of art are you making?
Find a triangle. Find a square. How are they the same? How are they different?
Can you write about a shape you see? Use words and numbers.
Can you draw a triangle? Can you draw a square?
Look at the foam letters A and O. Which letter looks like a triangle? Which looks like a circle?
Use blocks to make a square.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builder: Motivation and Creativity; Social Development

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder take initiative and introduce vocabulary (practice).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to More-igami.
Read closely to discuss initiative and review familiar shapes.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Create, compose, decompose, and talk about common two-dimensional shapes, including circle, square, rectangle, and triangle; Combine shapes to create a picture or design; Explain that a shape remains the same shape even when its size or position changes.
Take initiative.
Engage with trusted adults and peers to work, communicate, and play.
Use art for self-expression.
Understand and use category words.
Communicate nonverbally with peers who speak a different language.
Experiment with a variety of fine-motor tasks.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Guide children to create ladybug origami using the directions on pages 32–33 of More-igami.
Help children describe the shapes they create.
Discuss taking initiative and practicing.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we express ourselves through making art?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Tell me about the main character, the most important person or animal in your story.
What does it look like to be brave and strong?
Choose your favorite shape. Why do you like it?
Write a story with you in it. What problem do you have? How will you solve that problem?
Work with a friend to create something together.
Make a design out of your favorite letters.
Use different shapes to build a very strong tower.

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. More-igami by Dori Kleber, illustrated by G. Brian Karas. Text copyright © 2016 by Dori Kleber. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photos © Shutterstock: markers (nikkytok), paper (jannoon028).

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to discuss geometry, engage children with art, and introduce vocabulary (pyramid).
Begin Story Time by revisiting More-igami and asking, How did Joey learn to make origami?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension and to review two- and three-dimensional shapes.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize, name, and describe common two-dimensional shapes; Begin to recognize common three-dimensional shapes, describing them as balls, boxes, cans, and cones.
Describe and sort objects by similarities and differences.
Take initiative.
Experiment with a variety of fine-motor tasks.
Use art for self-expression.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children pick an object from a bag.
Ask children to describe the object and sort it by whether it is flat or not.
Discuss the properties of two- and three-dimensional shapes.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we express ourselves through making art?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Where do you see shapes in this book?
Pretend to climb the side of a very big pyramid!
How is a pyramid like a triangle? How is it different?
Write about what kind of art you like best.
Can you make a not-flat shape like a box or a ball?
Write your name. Do you see any shapes in your name? Which shapes?
Can you build a pyramid?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. More-igami by Dori Kleber, illustrated by G. Brian Karas. Text copyright © 2016 by Dori Kleber. Illustrations copyright © 2016 by G. Brian Karas. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Candlewick Press. Photo © jannoon028/Shutterstock.

tg_materials-caption.tg_materials-caption_book-title-Ital: Big Chart of Big Ideas: A Horse, of Course

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Social Development; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about different genres of art, engage children with movement, and introduce vocabulary (sculpt, mold).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts A Horse, of Course and More-igami.
Read interactively and connect to classification by sorting types of artwork.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Create, compose, decompose, and talk about common two-dimensional shapes, including circle, square, rectangle, and triangle; Combine shapes to create a picture or design; Begin to recognize common three-dimensional shapes, describing them as balls, boxes, cans, and cones.
Describe and sort objects by similarities and differences; Collect, organize, and present data graphically.
Engage with trusted adults and peers to work, communicate, and play.
Take initiative.
Experiment with a variety of small-motor tasks.
Separate a sentence into words.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Ask children to sculpt anything they like using modeling clay.
Guide children to sort their creations into categories.
Help children create a bar graph.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we express ourselves through making art?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Choose two pictures in the book. Which one do you like better? Why?
Pretend to be a sculptor. What will you make?
Use Pattern Blocks to make a horse or another animal.
Write about two kinds of art you would like to try making.
What tools do you like to use best when you are drawing a picture? Why?
What sound do you hear at the beginning of sculpt? Can you write it?
Can you build a horse and a fence that is taller than the horse?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. More-igami by Dori Kleber, illustrated by G. Brian Karas. Text copyright © 2016 by Dori Kleber. Illustrations copyright © 2016 by G. Brian Karas. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Candlewick Press. Photo © Stephen Rees/Shutterstock.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photos © Shutterstock: clay (Stephen Rees), markers (nikkytok), paper (jannoon028).

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to practice making a rectangle and introduce vocabulary (master, patience).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the Big Book and asking, What can you do to become a master of something?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and a focus on geometry.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize, name, and describe common two-dimensional shapes; Begin to recognize common three-dimensional shapes.
Take initiative.
Experiment with a variety of fine-motor tasks.
Use art for self-expression.
Communicate nonverbally with peers who speak a different language.
Write for different purposes.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: What is your favorite way to create art?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s responses to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we express ourselves through making art?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Find a book illustration that you love. Tell a friend why you love it.
Pretend to display your best art in a museum. Describe your creation to a friend.
What art can you make from materials in this center?
Write about a child who loves making art.
What does your artwork tell people about yourself?
Use foam letters to create a work of art. Which letters did you use?
Choose three shapes that you like. Can you make a building out of those shapes?

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Name common shapes.
Slide, flip, and turn shapes to demonstrate that the shapes remain the same.
Show competence initiating social interactions.
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek adult help when necessary.
Delete a word from a compound word.
Use art as a form of creative self-expression and representation.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Create shapes.
Slide, flip, and turn shapes to demonstrate that the shapes remain the same.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Show competence initiating social interactions.
Use art as a form of creative self-expression and representation.
Show control of tasks that require small-muscle strength and control.
Name common shapes.
Sort objects that are the same and different into groups and use language to describe how the groups are similar and different.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek adult help when necessary.
Use art as a form of creative self-expression and representation.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Name common shapes.
Create shapes.
Collect data and organize it in a graphic representation.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek adult help when necessary.
Interact with a variety of playmates.
Show control of tasks that require small-muscle strength and control.
Separate a normally spoken four-word sentence into individual words.
Name common shapes.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Use art as a form of creative self-expression and representation.
Show control of tasks that require small-muscle strength and control.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Engage in various forms of nonverbal communication with those who do not speak native language.
